tit.e: Gun-ku-cho-son Henseiho (the law for reorganization of counties, wards, towns and villages)
Gun-ku-cho-son Henseiho (the law for reorganization of counties, wards, towns and villages)

sen.j: 郡区町村編制法（ぐんくちょうそんへんせいほう）は、1878年（明治11年）に制定された日本の地方制度に関する法令である。
sen.e: Gun-ku-cho-son Henseiho (the law for reorganization of counties, wards, towns and villages) was the law regarding a Japanese local government system, established in 1878.
Gun-ku-cho-son Henseiho (the law for reorganization of counties, wards, towns and villages) was the law regarding a Japanese local government system, established in 1878.
Gun-ku-cho-son Henseiho (the law for reorganization of counties, wards, towns and villages) was the law regarding a Japanese local government system, established in 1878.

sen.j: 沿革
sen.e: History
History
History

sen.j: いわゆる地方三新法の一つとして、1878年7月22日、太政官布告・太政官達第17号として制定された。
sen.e: This law, one of so-called "the three new bills related to the local government system," was enacted as Dajokan Fukoku or Tasshi (Edict or Proclamation of the Grand Council of State) No. 17 of July 22, 1878.

This law, one of the so-called three new bills related to the local government system, was enacted as Dajokan Fukoku or Tasshi (Edict or Proclamation of the Grand Council of State) No. 17 in July 22, 1878.
sen.cmt: 「so-called｣の前にtheをつけ、その後のクオーテーションを取りました。「7月22日に制定された」ので、ofをinにしました。
sen.e: This law, one of the so-called three new bills related to the local government system, was enacted as Dajokan Fukoku or Tasshi (Edict or Proclamation of the Grand Council of State) No. 17 in July 22, 1878.

sen.j: 従前の大区小区制が地方の実情に合わず不評であったことから、これを見直すために導入されたものである。
sen.e: It was introduced to review the previous Daiku-shoku Sei (a centralized district system that abolished all pre-existing towns, villages and their offices and institutions), which was unfavorable to popular feeling as the system did not meet local circumstances.

It was introduced to review the previous Daiku-shoku Sei (a centralized district system that abolished all pre-existing towns, villages and their offices and institutions), which had been unpopular as the system did not meet local circumstances.
sen.cmt: 「which was」を「which had been」にしました。「unfavorable to popular feeling」を「unpopular」にしました。
sen.e: It was introduced to review the previous Daiku-shoku Sei (a centralized district system that abolished all pre-existing towns, villages and their offices and institutions), which had been unpopular as the system did not meet local circumstances.

sen.j: 1888年（明治21年）に制定された市制・町村制、1890年（明治23年）に制定された府県制・郡制により（具体的には郡制附則の規定により同法施行時に）、各府県において1900年（明治33年）までに順次廃止または失効した。
sen.e: By 1900, Gun-ku-cho-son Henseiho was sequentially abolished or revoked in all prefectures since 1888 when Shi Sei (a system of cities) and Cho Son Sei (a system of towns and villages) were enacted and 1890 when Fu Ken Sei (a system of prefectures) and Gun Sei (a system of counties) were enacted (precisely enforced in accordance with the supplementary provision in Gun Sei).
sen.cmt: 市制: "Shi Sei (a system of cities)"町村制: Cho Son Sei (a system of towns and villages)府県制: Fu Ken Sei (a system of prefectures)郡制: Gun Sei (a system of counties)
sen.e: By 1900, Gun-ku-cho-son Henseiho was abolished or revoked one after another in every prefectures since 1888 when Shi Sei (a system of cities) and Cho Son Sei (a system of towns and villages) were enacted and 1890 when Fu Ken Sei (a system of prefectures) and Gun Sei (a system of counties) were enacted (precisely enforced in accordance with the supplementary provision in Gun Sei).
sen.cmt: 「sequentially」ほど秩序だっていないと思われましたので、「one after another」にし、「all」を「every」にしました。
sen.e: By 1900, Gun-ku-cho-son Henseiho was abolished or revoked one after another in every prefectures since 1888 when Shi Sei (a system of cities) and Cho Son Sei (a system of towns and villages) were enacted and 1890 when Fu Ken Sei (a system of prefectures) and Gun Sei (a system of counties) were enacted (precisely enforced in accordance with the supplementary provision in Gun Sei).

sen.j: 全6条、のち1880年（明治13年）の太政官布告第14号により3条が追加されて全9条。
sen.e: It consisted of six articles and later nine articles after three articles were added by Dajokan Fukoku No. 14 of 1880.

sen.j: 従来の大区小区制を廃して、郡区町村を置くことを定めた（第1条）。
sen.e: It stipulated abolishment of the traditional Daiku-shoku Sei and establishment of counties, wards, towns and villages. (Article 1)
It stipulated abolishment of the traditional Daiku-shoku Sei and establishment of counties, wards, towns and villages. (Article 1)
It abolished the traditional Daiku-shoku Sei and established counties, wards, towns and villages in their place (Article 1).

sen.j: 郡町村の名称と区域は江戸時代のものを継承した（第2条）。
sen.e: As for the names and territories of counties, towns and villages, those made in the Edo period were continued to be used. (Article 2)
As for the names and territories of counties, towns and villages, those made in the Edo period were continued to be used. (Article 2)
The names and territories of counties, towns and villages established in the Edo period could continue to be used (Article 2).

sen.j: 郡
sen.e: County
Countries
Countries

sen.j: 郡は、広すぎるものを分割した上で（第3条）、一人の郡長を置いた（第5条前段）。
sen.e: Large counties were divided (Article 3) and a Guncho (county mayor) was placed by county (The first part of Article 5).
sen.cmt: 郡長: 呼称（役職名）として音訳を残します。（後の区長、戸長も同様）
sen.e: Large counties were divided (Article 3) and a Guncho (county mayor) was placed by county (The first part of Article 5).
Large counties were divided (Article 3) and a Guncho (county mayor) was placed by county (The first part of Article 5).

sen.j: 郡が狭い場合には、複数の郡に一人の郡長を置くこともあった（第5条後段）。
sen.e: In some cases, one Guncho governed multiple counties if the counties were small. (The latter part of Article 5)
When the county was small, one Guncho governed multiple counties (The latter part of Article 5).
sen.cmt: 「In some cases,･･･if the countries were small」を「When the country was small」にしました。
sen.e: When the county was small, one Guncho governed multiple counties (The latter part of Article 5).

sen.j: なお条文上に明記されていないが、郡の役所は郡役所と称した。
sen.e: An office of a county was called "Gunyakusho" (county office) although it was not specified in the law.

sen.j: また、郡長は官選とされた。
sen.e: The Guncho was appointed by the government.

sen.j: 区
sen.e: Ward
Wards
Wards

sen.j: 三府・条約港日本の条約港および人口密集地には、郡から分けて区を置き、広い人口密集地には複数の区を置いた（第4条）。
sen.e: Wards were established within counties exclusively in the three urban prefectures, opening port cities and densely-populated areas, and multiple wards were placed in large densely-populated areas. (Article 4)

Wards were established within counties exclusively in the three urban prefectures, treaty port cities and densely-populated areas, and multiple wards were placed in large densely-populated areas (Article 4).
sen.cmt: 「条約港」は、辞書に「treaty port」とありましたので、その語をあてました。
sen.e: Wards were established within counties exclusively in the three urban prefectures, treaty port cities and densely-populated areas, and multiple wards were placed in large densely-populated areas (Article 4).

sen.j: 区には区長を置いた（第5条）。
sen.e: A Kucho (ward mayor) was assigned in each ward (Article 5).
A Kucho (ward mayor) was assigned in each ward (Article 5).
A Kucho (ward mayor) was assigned in each ward (Article 5).

sen.j: 区長も郡長と同様、官選とされた。
sen.e: Like a Guncho, the Kucho was appointed by the government.
Like a Guncho, the Kucho was appointed by the government.

sen.j: 国勢調査以前の日本の人口統計主要都市人口で見ると、日本三大都市の東京には麹町区以下東京15区、大阪には東区 (大阪市)・西区 (大阪市)・南区 (大阪市)・北区 (大阪市)の4区、京都には上京区・下京区の2区が置かれた。
sen.e: Regarding the three largest cities according to the major city population statistics before a census was started, Tokyo had 15 wards including Kojimachi Ward, and Osaka had four wards; Higashi Ward (Osaka City), Nishi Ward (Osaka City), Minami Ward (Osaka City) and Kita Ward (Osaka City), and Kyoto had two wards; Kamigyo Ward and Shimogyo Ward.

Regarding the three largest cities, according to the major city population statistics before a census was started, Tokyo had 15 wards including Kojimachi Ward, and Osaka had four wards; Higashi Ward (Osaka City), Nishi Ward (Osaka City), Minami Ward (Osaka City) and Kita Ward (Osaka City), and Kyoto had two wards; Kamigyo Ward and Shimogyo Ward.
sen.cmt: 原文「～で見ると、日本三大都市の」なので、「according」の前にピリオドを入れました。(ピリオドがないと、「～による日本三大都市の」の意味になると思われるので。）
sen.e: Regarding the three largest cities, according to the major city population statistics before a census was started, Tokyo had 15 wards including Kojimachi Ward, and Osaka had four wards; Higashi Ward (Osaka City), Nishi Ward (Osaka City), Minami Ward (Osaka City) and Kita Ward (Osaka City), and Kyoto had two wards; Kamigyo Ward and Shimogyo Ward.

sen.j: その他は都市毎に1区ずつが置かれ、名古屋市・金沢市・広島市・和歌山市・横浜市・仙台市・堺市・福岡市・熊本市・神戸市・新潟市・岡山市・長崎市・函館市・赤間関市・札幌市が設置された

sen.j: なお、赤間関区20,966人、札幌区2,678人など本籍人口が少ない都市に区が設置され、富山・鹿児島・福井・徳島等の本籍人口が比較的多い都市に区が設置されなかった経緯については不明である。
sen.e: And it is unknown why wards were established in the low population cities such as Akamagaseki Ward (20,966 people) and Sapporo Ward (2,678 people) while no wards were done in the cities with a relatively large population such as Toyama, Kagoshima, Fukui and Tokushima.

sen.e: A Kocho (head of towns and villages) was assigned in towns and villages.

sen.j: 戸長は民選の後、府県知事の任命により就任した。
sen.e: The Kucho was elected by the public and appointed by the Prefecture governor.
The Kucho was elected by the public and then appointed by the Prefecture governor.

sen.j: 制度の狙い
sen.e: Purpose of the system
Purpose of the system
Purpose of the system

sen.j: 旧来の郡町村制に戻し人民の便宜を図ると同時に、戸長を民選とすることにより地方に一定の自治を認めた。
sen.e: It restored the traditional county, town and village system for the convenience of the public as well as granted a certain level of local autonomy by introducing the public election for the Kocho.

This law restored the traditional county, town and village system for the convenience of the public as well as granted a certain level of local autonomy by introducing the public election for the Kocho.
sen.cmt: 冒頭「It」は曖昧です。動詞が「restored」ですので「This law｣にしました。「The purpose of the system」を主語として「was to」で受けることも考えられますが、原文に近い形の訳文にしました。
sen.e: This law restored the traditional county, town and village system for the convenience of the public as well as granted a certain level of local autonomy by introducing the public election for the Kocho.

sen.j: しかしその一方で、官選である郡長・区長が戸長の上に位置し、また郡長・区長が同じく官選である府県知事の指揮下に置かれ、その府県知事を内務省 (日本)が指揮することで、中央集権の体制維持も図ったのである。
sen.e: Meanwhile, it aimed to preserve the centralized government system by placing the Guncho and Kucho, who were appointed by the government, in a stronger position than the Kocho, while putting them under the direction of the Prefecture governor, who was appointed likewise and directed by the prewar Ministry of Home Affairs.

Meanwhile, it aimed to maintain the centralized government system by placing the Guncho and Kucho, who were appointed by the government, in a higher position than the Kocho, while putting them under the direction of the Prefecture governor, who was appointed likewise and directed by the prewar Ministry of Home Affairs.
sen.cmt: 「preserve」を「maintain」にしました。「stronger」を「higher」にしました。Isn't "direction"a strong word in this context? I think milder word like "control" or "administration" would be better.
sen.e: Meanwhile, it aimed to maintain the centralized government system by placing the Guncho and Kucho, who were appointed by the government, in a higher position than the Kocho, while putting them under the control of the Prefecture governor, who was appointed likewise and directed by the prewar Ministry of Home Affairs.
sen.cmt: チェッカーのコメント通りdirection →controlにしました。

sen.j: いわゆる『部落解体』を行い中央集権体制を作ろうとしたが、地方におけるまとまりが強く達成することができなかった。
sen.e: It was meant to establish the centralized administrative framework through so-called "hamlet demise," which did not come true due to a strong connection local communities had.
It was meant to establish the centralized administrative framework through the so-called "hamlet demise," which was not accomplished due to a strong connection local communities had.
sen.cmt: 「so-called｣の前にtheを入れました。「did not come true」を「was not accomplished」としました。
sen.e: It was meant to establish the centralized administrative framework through the so-called "hamlet demise," which was not accomplished due to a strong connection local communities had.
